sections.title: Vol I Sec 2 Emergency Preparedness
sections.summary: Emergency preparedness, emergency response plans, medical emergencies, and drill documentation.

subpolicies.title: Emergency Lighting Testing
subpolicies.summary: Monthly/annual emergency lighting tests and documentation.

blocks.text: The Safety Officer or designee shall test emergency lighting on a monthly (30-day) schedule.
Emergency lighting findings are documented in the Fire Alarm/Emergency Lighting System Operations Log.
Test the lighting unit’s battery operation for 30 seconds (monthly/quarterly) and for 1.5 hours annually, per manufacturer requirements.
Failed tests are documented and re-testing is performed once corrected.
After storms or power outages, emergency lights and illuminated exit signs are checked to confirm battery operation.

subpolicies.pdf: pdf/QBH Procedures Manual Vol I Sec 2 Emergency Preparedness.pdf

subpolicies.title: Emergency Management Plan
subpolicies.summary: Facility emergency response, preparedness, communication, and recovery.

blocks.text: QBH maintains 24-hour telephone answering capability to respond to facility emergencies and keeps medication dosage information accessible for staff on call.
The plan is reviewed at least annually and after any major emergency or drill; improvement opportunities are evaluated and documented.
Emergency codes are used on the intercom/phone system to indicate events (e.g., evacuation required, fire, bomb threat, blackout, behavior control, chemical spill).
Preparedness includes staff knowledge checks and maintaining an up-to-date plan for emergency administration of medications if the program must close temporarily.
Response includes notifying authorities as needed, establishing a control center, assigning staff duties, and accounting for all staff/visitors/consumers.
Evacuation routes are posted; supervisors coordinate orderly movement to safe areas and ensure accountability.
Mitigation procedures address scenarios such as fire/explosion, severe weather, bomb threat, loss of utilities, earthquake, flood, chemical spill, and pandemic.
Recovery and disaster records protection steps are defined, including safeguarding paper/electronic records and ensuring continuity of operations.

subpolicies.pdf: pdf/QBH Procedures Manual Vol I Sec 2 Emergency Preparedness.pdf

subpolicies.title: Medical Emergency Procedure
subpolicies.summary: Supplies, actions during/after medical emergencies, and reporting.

blocks.text: First aid and basic life-support supplies and protective barrier equipment are available and staff are oriented to their locations.
In a medical emergency, call 911 if the person is unconscious, has trouble breathing, or appears seriously injured; do not hang up until instructed.
Qualified staff may render first aid/CPR; universal precautions are required.
After the incident, provide follow-up information to responders and report the incident to the Clinical Director and Safety Officer.
Policies/procedures are reviewed annually and revised as needed; revisions are submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval.

subpolicies.pdf: pdf/QBH Procedures Manual Vol I Sec 2 Emergency Preparedness.pdf

subpolicies.title: MAT Program Emergencies Policy
subpolicies.summary: Handling program closures/disasters, displaced consumers, medication planning, and diversion concerns.

blocks.text: QBH should be positioned to receive displaced consumers due to emergency closure/disaster, making every effort to contact the home treatment program.
In emergencies, program personnel may disclose medication information to a program physician/RN/DO without signed consent when needed for medical emergency care.
Medication planning: maintain take-home dose procedures and ensure doses are provided only on appropriate days/times per policy.
Diversion/illicit drug use concerns: procedures include objective evidence, monitoring, and appropriate clinical actions per treatment plan.
Documentation and coordination steps are included for displaced consumers who need continued access to MAT services.

subpolicies.pdf: pdf/QBH Procedures Manual Vol I Sec 2 Emergency Preparedness.pdf

subpolicies.title: Emergency Generator Operating and Testing
subpolicies.summary: Generator testing schedule, documentation, and fuel supply requirements.

blocks.text: The Safety Officer or designee maintains and tests the emergency generator per manufacturer specifications (including routine run time and annual load testing).
Testing is documented in the Emergency Generator Testing Log and filed in the Safety Officer’s office.
If the generator does not start and required repairs are made, the unit is re-tested and results documented.
Fuel supplies are maintained at optimum levels and usage is recorded; an authorized fuel supplier arrangement is maintained.

subpolicies.title: Emergency Drill/Event Form
subpolicies.summary: Form used to document drills/events (fire, security breach, disaster, etc.).

blocks.text: Record drill location, date, type of drill/event, whether outside assistance was involved, time, total staff/patients/visitors accounted for, and action plan.
Use the form to document outcomes and any needed improvements.

subpolicies.title: Emergency Evacuation Drill/Event Analysis
subpolicies.summary: Checklist/analysis used to evaluate response and track corrective actions.

blocks.text: Evaluate staff understanding of evacuation/emergency duties and whether critical supplies/equipment were accessible.
Document issues, needed actions, staff assigned, and target achievement dates.

sections.title: Vol II Sec 6 Waived Lab
sections.summary: Consumer drug screening procedures and waived laboratory policy (CLIA compliance).

subpolicies.title: Consumer Drug Screening
subpolicies.summary: Urine drug screening purpose, frequency, handling, documentation, and result sharing.

blocks.text: Drug testing (especially urine testing) is used as a screening and diagnostic/therapeutic tool to monitor substance use and support treatment planning.
Screening tests are not confirmatory and may not meet forensic requirements; if false positives/negatives are suspected, a confirmatory test may be ordered.
Testing may include opiates, benzodiazepines, barbiturates, cocaine, marijuana/THC, methadone (and metabolites), amphetamines, alcohol, and other substances as appropriate.
Use for diagnosis: objective evidence may be necessary during intake when recent substance use status is unclear.
Use in treatment: drug testing can support contingency contracting/behavioral therapies and deter substance use, especially with random intervals.
Minimum testing frequency guidance includes intake screening; more frequent testing early in treatment; and periodic/random testing thereafter per treatment plan.
Test results should be discussed promptly with the consumer and documented in the consumer’s record along with interventions.
Sharing results: release to authorities generally requires consumer authorization or a valid court order consistent with confidentiality laws.
Specimen handling includes collection controls, potential direct observation when indicated, and measures to reduce tampering (e.g., temperature checks, pocket checks, securing belongings).
Confirmatory lab analysis is performed only when ordered by the Medical Director.

subpolicies.pdf: pdf/QBH Procedures Manual Vol II Sec 6 Waived Lab.pdf

subpolicies.title: Waived Lab Policy
subpolicies.summary: Waived lab equipment use, responsibilities, quality control, training, and annual review.

blocks.text: Information obtained using waived lab equipment shall be used primarily for screening and to support clinical care decisions.
Results of waived lab procedures shall not be used as the sole basis for making a diagnosis.
All waived lab procedures must comply with the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) Act of 1998.
The CEO is responsible for maintaining current CLIA waived lab certification authorizing the use of waived lab equipment.
Waived lab test results shall be recorded in the consumer’s medical record.
Lab procedures beyond those authorized under the CLIA Certificate of Waiver shall be performed by a certified external laboratory.
The Lead Nurse or designee shall maintain an inventory of waived lab equipment and related certificates at each site.
Protocols must be maintained for specimen collection, preservation, calibration, documentation, and corrective actions.
Only staff verified as competent and trained may perform waived laboratory testing.
Quality control records, test results, and instrument logs shall be retained for a minimum of two years.
Training and competency verification for waived lab testing shall occur at orientation and at least annually thereafter.
The Lead Nurse shall review this policy annually and submit revisions to the Clinical Committee as required.
